utterances: And Jacklyn, did any of those things happen?
Oh, of course not since I just heard that scam story, I was really - my hackles were kind of - my antennae were up.
Good for you then.
OK.
So make the phone call.
Well, so listen to public radio and call your grandson.
Those are the two things we're learning here today.
You know, they did tell me something at the FTC when I talked to the person there.
He said, you know, just take those checks and then show them to your local bank just so they know what they look like.
OK.
Well, they look very good unfortunately.
They look very, very good these days.
They were practically identical, the scale was a little different on them but they were, you know, it was obvious it was from the same thing even though the stories were totally different.
Jacklyn, thanks very much and congratulations.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can get one more caller in.
This is Lenard(ph).
Lenard with us from Tucson, Arizona.
Hi.
How you doing?
All right, Lenard.
So the same thing happened to me but at my work.
I work for a private upscale hotel and one night we got a phone call from one of the employees that was one of the banquet managers, and he said he was calling from Canada, but he gotten mugged.
And, the weird thing is that it sounded exactly like him.
But there's something that seems so off about it.
But, I called my manager and like, you know, this person from the phone, saying he got mugged, and he's needing money.
He's at the ticket counter, at the airport, and we to Western Union him like - it was something like four or $500.
And, my manager thought about it for a second, he goes, well OK that's fine.
And so I was actually about to go to Western Union, and the guy was on the phone this whole time and then finally, my manager calls back.
He said, no, no, no. I just talked to the employee, and he doesn't know what we're talking about.
He's actually at home reading a book.
Ah ha.
And I was like.
Oh, my goodness, and so I went back on the phone.
And, for some reason my manager just didn't want me to let him know that we knew it was a scam, and so I just told him no. And when I told him no he got really whiny and complaining.
He was like why?
You were just about to do it, and I'm like no. He goes, well then can you do it?
Can you wire me some money?
And, I was like, no. Then, I just hung up.
Yeah.
So, it was just kind of interesting.
I always thought that I would be able to recognize things like that.
But, I almost fell for it which was kind of funny like.
Well, as Alison says, they're really good and the fact of the matter is, calling, checking, anything else that you would advise for people to do if they're suspicious?
In this particular scam, just call and check it out.
And, you know, even though the kid tells you not to call the parents, call the parents.
You know, go ahead and do it.
So the kid's going to get in trouble.
It's worth finding out.
And Chris Painter, we'll ask you for advise on the Cyber scams in just a minute, but we have to take a short break.
So, please stay with us.
Chris Painter is the deputy assistant director of the Cyber Division of the FBI.
Also with us, Alison Preszley you just heard from of the Better Business Bureau.
They're both with us here in Studio Three-A.
We're talking about scams, new varieties on old scams.
Old varieties on new scams.
Give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email us talk@npr.org.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
In Illinois this week, the Cook County sheriff charged some 20 inmates for running a scam that ran up more than $50,000 in phone bills.
One man outside Boston lost thousands of dollars in another scam.
A caller told him he'd won a lottery overseas, and he sent what he believed was taxes on the prize money.
Today we're talking about the latest generation of scams and cons.
Our guests are Alison Preszler of the Better Business Bureau and Chris Painter, deputy assistant director of the Cyber Division of the FBI.
They're both with us here in Studio A.
Chris, before we went away, you were about to tell us some advise on what to do when you start getting these emails that looked tantalizing?
Well, one thing is to use the same degree of caution and skepticism as you would in the physical world.
Just because it's on the Internet doesn't mean you should not use your ordinary common sense.
Look at things skeptically.
If you're got an email from someone you don't know, and it looks too good to be true, it's too good to be true.

And, in fact, there's a website the FBI participates in, it's called lookstoogoodtobetrue.com that has a lot of advise for consumers, and also talks about a lot of the reasons scams that are out there so people can go to one place and look at some of those things.
Another thing to do is you know, don't click on the link.
I mentioned this earlier.
If you get an email from someone you don't know, and it asks you to click on a link and go to a site don't do that.
And type in the website yourself.
Don't give people your credit card numbers without figuring out that this is actually a secure site for something you want to do.
These are kind of common sense sorts of things that you should do.
But, you also ought to make sure your computer is secure.
I talked about these malicious codes that could be downloaded when you visit some of these sites.
Make sure you have an anti-virus software.
Make sure you have...
Even if you've got a Mac.
Even if you've got a Mac.
Yeah.
Look, Macs have more market share now.
They're going to be targets too.
That's, you know, it's across the board.
People - criminals are endlessly inventive, and they're looking for the money.
Where the money is where they're going to go.

One other thing I would comment on this - I think we talked probably the top of the hour about people being concerned that law enforcement really couldn't do a lot about some of these crimes, and I think you know, obviously, the criminals have become pretty smart at hiding their electronic and digital foot prints and one of the reasons - that's one of or the reasons we're trying to get inside these organizations in the beginning.

Laurent Gbagbo says that this is what rebels do when they take a town, and then Alassane Ouattara has said this is what the Liberian mercenaries, who work for Laurent Gbagbo have done once we left town.

I think that one thing is for sure is that this town and this region, the western region on the border with Liberia, it's a very violent and volatile region that has a long history of sort of interethnic violence.
But people should not assume because their individual loss is relatively small that it's something that we're not interested in.
There is a - it's something called, the Internet Crimes Complaint Center which is set up specifically for people who are victims to go to the site, ic3.gov.
You go to that site, and you fill in a claim form.

You essentially fill in a complaint form, but then it's pooled with forms from all over the rest of the country and often, even if they set up shop and close down shops as Alison said, often they're setting up a new scheme, and you can start linking these people together and really go after them.
Find patterns like that.
Yeah.
Alison, are there resources that you would recommend?
Well, I would absolutely recommend that if someone has become victim of a scam that they can file a complaint with their Better Business Bureau.
We don't have the regulatory power and we don't have you know, all the awesome resources...
Wait a minute, I've seen your thugs on the street.
Yeah.
We're pretty tough looking.
But, we can help raise awareness so that other people don't fall victims to these same types of scams.

And, then also I recommend that you do your research before you do business with the company that you're not familiar with check them out online at the Better Business Bureau website, you can look at the reliability report for free.
And we also post alerts about scams that are happening.
Well, thanks to you both.
We appreciate your time and your willingness to come in to join us here in Studio Three-A today.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Alison Preszler of the Better Business Bureau and Chris Painter, the deputy assistant director of the Cyber Division of the FBI.
Coming up, we'll be talking about - well, revising reality with photo shop.
Tomorrow, many of you will be hitting the road for Thanksgiving.
We'll talk with Tom Vanderbilt about his book, ""Traffic: Why We Drive The Way We Do and What It Says About Us,"" and yes, we will be here on Thanksgiving Day to take your calls.
You might remember the WPA state guides of the 1930s.
The idea was to describe America to Americans.
Well, we want you to contribute to that tradition.
Send us a short essay about 100 words to tell us what makes your home state special, it's humor and the accent, it's peculiarities and biases.
Email us your essay to talk@npr.org put state in the subject line if you would and you might get a chance to read it on the air on Thanksgiving Day.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm David Greene.
The battle for the leadership of Ivory Coast is raging on the streets of Abidjan today.
Forces loyal to Alassane Ouattara, who won last November's presidential election, are in the city making a final push to try and oust the incumbent president, Laurent Gbagbo.
He's refused to leave office and his own forces fighting desperately to hang on to the presidential palace.
The showdown between the two camps comes in the wake of news on Saturday that hundreds of people were massacred in a town in Ivory Coast's cocoa-producing region.
It's not yet known who carried out those murders and why.
We're joined on the line by Associated Press reporter Marco Chown Oved, who's in Abidjan.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Tell us the latest on the situation on the ground.
You actually have filed a report that forces loyal to Alassane Ouattara, the recognized winner of the presidential election, are making a final push now.
Well, what we really should put an emphasis on here is that these forces loyal to Alassane Ouattara were able to take 80, 90 percent of the country in two or three days.
They swept across the country meeting almost no resistance, that is until they arrived here on the doorstep of the biggest city, Abidjan.
Since then, we've been expecting the city to fall at any moment but now it's the fourth day since the siege of Abidjan began.
And while there is still continued fighting, we hear the explosions of mortars and the sort of rat-tat-tat of automatic gunfire.
The city's still being fought for neighborhood-by-neighborhood, and I guess most importantly, the president, Laurent Gbagbo still controls the television and both the presidential palaces.

And speaking of the presidential palace, is that where we think the incumbent president who's refusing to leave, Laurent Gbagbo, is actually and is he in there and any chance that he'll surrender at some point?
What he's definitely said that he has no intention of surrendering.
He has repeated it on television.
His advisers, every time we speak to them, will tell us that: that this is not a question of surrendering.
But as far as exact location, that is, of course, a big mystery.
His advisers say that he is inside the presidential palace but we've had conflicting reports about seeing cars and convoys, even boats, leaving.
